REVISED STRUCTURE OF EDUCATION
(Paper Misc. 3 of 1979)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Amendments [28th March, 1979] to Question [27th March 1979].

    "That this House having noted the Report on the Ministry of Education, 1978, contained in Paper Misc. 3 of 1979,

    (1) supports the revised structure of education which will allow each pupil to study at a pace suited to his learning capacity and which will make him as bilingual as he can be,

    (2) approves flexibility in implementation particularly to accommodate the wishes of parents,

    (3) recommends periodic adjustments and changes to the revised structure which experience and advice of principals and teachers show to be desirable in the long term interests of pupils.". - (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education).

Which Amendments were,

    (i) at end, to add a comma and the following new sub-paragraph -

    "(4) resolves that the Minister of Education do report to Parliament after 2 or 3 years on the progress, unresolved problems and state of implementation of the revised structure of education". - (Mr Fong Sip Chee, Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour);

    (ii) at end, to add a comma and the following 2 new sub-paragraphs -

    "(4) advocates that the Ministry of Education collates the suggestions and criticisms raised during the debate in the House.

    (5) urges the Ministry to study the implications of policy changes in depth and to give schools and parents adequate lead time to implement such policies". - (Dr Toh Chin Chye, Minister for Health).

    Question again proposed, "That the comma and new sub-paragraph (4), proposed to be added by the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour, be there added."

     Mr Speaker: As had been agreed, the debate may range over both amendments and the original Question. Dr Tan.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, over the last few days we have listened to many speeches in this House on the subject of education; some eloquent, some wise and some humorous. But if there is any one factor which emerges from the

Column: 250

presentation of the speeches, it is this. On the subject of education, as on no other, everybody considers himself an expert. The objectives which have been outlined by hon. Members have been many and varied, recommendations profuse.

    If I may just draw attention to three points brought up by three Ministers for illustration. One Senior Minister thought that having two languages, like English and Chinese, involves a cancelling out process. However, he seems to have been affected by the New Mathematics which he has been studying together with his daughter. One minus one does not equal one, but equals zero. He said that because one language cancels out the other, therefore you get a monolingual product. Another Minister wants the standard of the second language to be higher than that provided for by the Goh Report. Yet another wants more time to play marbles. We have got to be realistic. We can be wide-ranging in our objectives but we have to look at the resources available to us. We cannot turn the Education Ministry nor the teachers into supermen and superwomen. We cannot achieve everything that we desire even if these objectives are all valued and worthy ones. There is a time constraint. There is a nerve constraint on the part of those who are being subjected to the process.

    Perhaps the value of the Goh Report is in pointing out the tremendous wastage of our system. I find the wastage shocking, not merely in terms of literacy as pointed out but, as on the first chapter, page 3, that there seems to be a correlation between illiteracy and drug abuse, delinquency, attempted suicide, and court martials. In other words, there are disciplinary problems of various kinds. We have got to stop and think not merely in terms of why or how this illiteracy has come about but, more fundamentally, why the products of our schools are so prone to such delinquency.

    There is one point which the Report did not cover. Perhaps the sheer size of the task did not provide enough time but which we ought to look at over time, that is, what about those 39% who eventually attain three GCE

Column: 251

'O' level passes and the 40% who fail to attain three GCE 'O' level passes. What kind of students are we producing here? What are their values and attitudes? One Member brought up an important point, namely, that we seem to be hearing and reading reports about very highly educated people, professionals, who are criminals. These are the ones who surface and get caught, but how many countless others have gotten away? Sir, it will be interesting to find out what the graduates' values and attitudes are.

    The Motion standing in the name of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education is one which, I think, most of us can support. It is harmlessly stated and has some utility in terms of highlighting that each person should be given the chance to proceed at his or her own pace, which should have been obvious many years ago. It is quite strange that we have only now paid attention to this problem. I think one can improve the Motion in various ways as some of the Members have done, but what is more fundamental is the process of implementation. For all the good intentions and all the good objectives it is the implementation which is going to be crucial. Here the Prime Minister put his finger on the problem correctly. If I may quote him: [page vi, paragraph 30]

    'However, the more fundamental principle of good education is recognition by the Ministry that the basic teaching organisational unit is the school.'

Here again, one would have thought that this was a rather obvious point but it took the Prime Minister to bring it to the attention of the Ministry of Education.

    The problem is that there has been too much concern with the exercise of power by civil servants in Singapore. Just look at the principals and teachers having to hurry to some obscure counter at the Ministry of Education to receive a circular or the most recent order on what to do and what not to do, or the latest changes to be implemented. Little account was taken of their views and reactions. Little account was taken of their morale and, more fundamentally, no account

Column: 252

was taken of the values and attitudes of the teachers themselves. Even the Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour, a man whom I respect for his linguistic and other abilities, in pointing out the problem of teachers' morale and the need to do something about it, referred to them as "digits". Perhaps his encounters with the Prime Minister have resulted in some of the terminologies rubbing off on him.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Close influence.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, this is something which we want to pay particular attention to and many Members of Parliament have complained that the question of teachers' morale has been dismissed too easily in the Report. If I were a teacher and I got this bright young systems engineer coming to me asking all sorts of questions: are you fed up?

     An hon. Member: Yes.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Are you happy with your pay?

     An hon. Member: No.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Are you happy with your principals and officials of the Ministry of Education? I would be rather hesitant to be frank and honest in conveying my true feelings and views. It would have been better if a questionnaire had been sent out to all school teachers and principals anonymously. I would think that the result would be drastically different.

    On this question of proper treatment of people, since we are making much use of Confucianist ethics, I would like to quote the English translation of The Analects of Confucius by Arthur Waley: [page 88, paragraph 3]

    'The Master said, Govern the people by regulations, keep order among them by chastisements, and they will flee from you, and lose all self-respect. Govern them by moral force, keep order among them by ritual and they will keep their self-respect and come to you of their own accord.'

Interesting, is it not, Sir?

     An hon. Member: Very wise.

Column: 253



     Dr Augustine Tan: We subscribe to Confucianist ideals but why do not the people who govern, the people who hand down orders, listen to what the Master has to say? If people are treated with proper respect and given their proper due, their creativity will be released. They can flower in their professions. We have the recent example of women doctors being berated in this House for watching the clock. We might advise them to buy watches instead. But they came out with a reply to the Minister for Health. They stood up to him like a man!

    Sir, the medical students were chastised by the Member for Anson and reminded of their debt to the ground. It is a valid point. We can turn around and chastise and scold many other people, professionals, intellectuals, academics, teachers, and any small group that does not have the voting power; we can do that. But let us remember one point. These groups may be minorities in terms of voting power but they too have rights. Their principles are principles. Truth is truth. In the case of these medical students, there can be no question that the principle of bonding is correct. But how they go about doing it is important, and the "how" tells us whether we have got the refinements that Confucius told us we ought to have, or we simply rub people's heads into the dirt.

    University lecturers too have their grouses. It is not uncommon for university lecturers to be hauled up by a petty administrator at the university, sometimes even a former student who has assumed the position of Assistant Registrar, to be told what to do and what not to do, or which agency to turn to buy a particular plane ticket even if it should cost twice as much as some other agency, and so forth. Sir, I could tell this House endless tales of this sort - where people feel that they are not treated properly and that they are not given their due. Sir, if Singapore were to survive as a state respected by others, we need to produce people who can stand up for their rights. So to those people whose rights are trampled upon but who have the guts to stand up and point out what is wrong, I say, more power to them.

Column: 254



    Now, let me turn to page 35 of the Goh Report. I am sorry. It is a very confusing system. It is Chapter 3, page 5. The last paragraph (5.1) talks about the "Pupils' Home Background", and I quote:

    'Good schools have higher percentages of pupils from better home background, in terms of pupils' fathers' occupation and educational level than the other schools. In both the Chinese and English streams, the differences in the percentages between the good schools and the poor schools are significant.'

Note, Sir, "better home background". Now, Sir, if we really want to give everybody an equal opportunity, I think we should stop and think in terms of that 20% who are going to be relegated to the lowest stream of the primary school and study what are the factors affecting these poor children. I think there have been studies which show that diet plays a very important role in terms of the concentration level of children when they are in school. If the children do not have a full breakfast, their concentration level suffers a severe decline by about 9 o'clock. The child gets fidgety, becomes mischievous and is penalised. He is simply unable to concentrate for the simple medical reason that the glucose level in his blood stream has fallen below normal. Are we doing anything about this? Do we realise that there are still many poor people among us who are struggling along and cannot provide proper food or a proper diet for their children?

    Many MPs have pointed out the need for study facilities. I have also pointed that out and I was therefore aghast when the National Library banned students from studying in the Library - a most unwarranted step. We simply evade problems when they become too great for us to face up to. If the ratio of library facilities to student population is too low, well, raise the ratio.

    Then, Sir, children who come from the middle class or upper middle class homes have got the benefit of tutors. We are therefore going to see an accentuation of income or wealth disparities under the new system, because there will be pressure to provide more tutors for the children so that they will go to the first two streams and not

Column: 255

the last. What about the poor? They will be left behind.

    Another factor we have got to bear in mind, Sir, is the role of parents in monitoring the performance of their children. Here we seem to contradict ourselves in terms of policy. The Ministry of Finance says that we need more labour, particularly more woman power, so that we will not have to rely too much on immigrant labour. So try and get more women to do the work. It will be good for the economy. But is it good for the soul of the youngsters who are going to be left behind? Is it good for their education? Is it good for their values and attitudes when their mothers slog away at an eight or nine-hour job per day? This is something for us to think about. Yes, there are economic benefits, but what about the social costs? Why do we not think in terms of providing half-day work for women? If women doctors watch the clock because they have to rush home to cook the evening meal, then there is a legitimate reason for them to do so. Why do we not let the women doctors work half-day at half-pay? It is a simple solution.

    Sir, another consequence of our policy is the small family that we have today. We are constrained by land - economic circumstances, no doubt. But have we stopped to think about the long-term implications of small families? Many of us here in this House come from large families. We have many brothers and sisters. There were fights, there were quarrels. There was deprivation in many cases. But there is one thing we learn from large families, that is, to share, to give and to take. I am afraid, Sir, that too many of our youngsters today do not know how to give. They only know how to take. They have too much pocket money, too many toys which, in any case, destroy creativity, and too much freedom, even freedom from parental control. We admonish parents to have small families so that they can have more facilities and more time for their children. Yes, they have more facilities and more money. More time? No, not for the children because the extra time is taken in

Column: 256

working for the mother so that the parents can have greater leisure outside. They can go out dancing and gambling. They do not mind the children. What the children have are the school's ECA, homework and TV. So the consequence over the long term is greater selfishness in our younger generation.

    I have had countless cases, Sir, of young men complaining to me at my "meet-the-people" sessions, furious with the Housing and Development Board for refusing to let them change the tenancy of their flats which they were about to buy. They had registered three or four years previously, to buy these flats, using their parents' names, brothers' names, and sisters' names because they were as yet single. But since then they have got married. And now the wife says, "Let us live alone by ourselves. There is a nice new four-room flat. Why do we want to bother with our parents, your parents especially?" So the young man went to the Housing Board and said, "I wish to take out the names of my parents, my brothers and sisters. Let them live in the rented flat where they are right now, and my wife and I will go to the new flat." The rented flat might be a one-room flat or a two-room flat. The new flat is a four-room flat or a five-room flat for two people. Of course, the Housing Board would say to them, "This cannot be done. If you wish to get a new flat, you have to take out a new registration number because you were not married at the time when you registered to buy a flat." They got mad with the Housing Board and came to me. I therefore explained to them and said, "Look, why don't you take your parents with you and then let them apply for a flat for themselves? It may take one or two years. They have put up with you for 24 or 25 years. Why can't you put with them for another one or two years?." This is the kind of attitude which our young people have. I am worried and I am sure the MPs here are worried too. If you have five or six children and half of them are not filial you will still be taken care of in your old age. But when you have one or two children, and half of them are not filial, you have had it.

    If I may turn to page 6, Chapter 3 of that Report. There are some interesting findings

Column: 257

here. One is that the Government-aided schools seem to have performed better. I will quote from paragraph 5.3.2:

    'While only 44% of all the schools are government-aided, 71% of the good schools are government-aided and 84% of the poor schools are government schools ...'.

Surely, Sir, this is something for us to pause, think, and ponder at length. Why should this be so? What is so special about the Government-aided schools?

    Paragraph 5.4 points out to "Other Factors - Dedication of teachers. Teacher's teaching method, and Quality of pupils." But these are dismissed in a sentence:

    'Besides those factors that have been considered in the previous paragraphs, there are many other factors which are intangible and yet important. They are:'

They are simply dismissed in one sentence. Sir, these qualitative factors - dedication of teachers, teacher's teaching method and quality of pupils - are obviously important. They are crucial elements to be considered. But since these are not amenable to the computer and the systems engineers do not know what to do with them, they have simply been brushed aside. Yet the very finding that 71% of the good schools are Government-aided schools should give them plenty of food for thought. Why is this the case? Why do the Government schools perform so badly? But no explanation has been provided.

    Another paragraph deals with the pupil-teacher ratio and it simply dismisses the idea because the finding was that despite the fact that there was a higher pupil-teacher ratio in the good schools the results of the good schools remain good and, therefore, there is no need to look into this pupil-teacher ratio. Absurd, is it not, Sir? If we are serious about raising the quality of our education, we should not base our reports on such spurious findings. There is such a thing as spurious correlations which simple human commonsense can tell systems engineers about.

    Now, Sir, we talk about market value. Let me just give an illustration from the University. After obtaining a first degree, a First Class Honours, a man goes off and

Column: 258

spends four or five years to get a Ph.D. in Philosophy. He comes back and joins the University. When the time for promotion comes and he is not promoted, he starts asking questions. He is told, "But what is your market value?" Of course, after teaching Philosophy for 10 or 15 years he would have no market value. That should be rather obvious. But he has got a special value - educational value. Look at the effect this has on the young graduates! The University is getting very short of staff. The brighter young graduates are not going to pursue higher degrees. What is the point? You slog away for four or five years to get a Ph.D. only to be told at the end of it that you have no market value. We had a better system before: Lecturers, Readers and Professors - just three grades. Today we have Lecturers, Associate Professors, Professors, and now Senior Professors. The British system is one thing. The American system is simply -

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of clarification. The Member mentioned some error of logic, error of inference on the part of the systems engineers. I just happened to return at that point. Can the Member give me the chapter and verse?

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Minister, are you referring to the Bible or to your Report?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, I have no pretensions to holiness of the hon. Member. It is the blue book, Sir.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Chapter 3, pages 5 and 6. There are quite a few offending paragraphs there. The Minister has the original copy. I am quoting from the printed version. I will give the paragraphs. They are paragraphs, 5.1, 5.3.2. 5.3.3, 5.4 and 5.5.

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Where is the error of logic?

     Dr Augustine Tan: The first point concerns the percentage of good schools: "71% of the good schools are government-aided schools and 84% of the poor schools are government schools ...".

Column: 259



     Dr Goh Keng Swee: These are statements of fact.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Yes. I am just wondering why these important statements of fact are not properly analysed.

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: The Member wants enlightenment on these?

     Dr Augustine Tan: I do not suffer from lack of enlightenment. But I think the Ministry perhaps could do with some.

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: If the Member knows the reasons, then I think the systems engineers are quite right in not giving him the reasons. However, let us not quibble. What is the Member's next point?

     Dr Augustine Tan: Paragraph 5.4 pointed to three important factors: Dedication of teachers, Teacher's teaching method, and Quality of pupils. I was just complaining that these factors were simply stated as "intangible and yet important." I was pointing out that this should be related to the difference in performance between the government and government-aided schools. That is one. The other point concerns the pupil-teacher ratio. The finding is perhaps spurious and should not inhibit the Ministry from pursuing the improvements to schools and lowering the pupil/teacher ratio. May I continue?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: All right.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, I was talking about some problems of the University. The British system is simply Lecturer, Reader, Professor. The American system is Assistant Professor, Associate Professor and Professor. But we have a system which fits neither one. We have Lecturer, Associate Professor, Professor and Senior Professor.

     An hon. Member: Senior Lecturer.

     Dr Augustine Tan: I am sorry. Thank you. There is a Senior Lecturer. So we have Lecturer, Senior Lecturer, Associate Professor, Professor and Senior Professor. The intention behind this system was good, namely, the University was losing too many staff and therefore greater pay should be

Column: 260

given to the teaching staff. However, if we look at the actual promotions, we find that people like doctors, Business Administration lecturers, lawyers get promoted more rapidly, not because they are intrinsically better in terms of education and educational value but because their market value is higher. This is one more example to illustrate this problem.

    The Member for Anson recognises this problem, Sir, and emphasised that we should look for quality of commitment and, I should add, professional excellence, academic excellence. Titles matter to people. Professionals are not so much concerned with pay if they are accorded proper status, proper respect. But if teachers and professors do not get the social esteem which they think is their due, then they can only feel aggrieved that they have lost out somewhere along the line. And if we add to this the huge discrepancies in pay between the civil service and the teaching profession, then I think the discontent gets all the greater. I think what is important for us to realise, Sir, is that from the point of view of new graduates, what are the inducements for them to go into a particular profession or career? In other words, the concept of opportunity cost is more important than market value. What has the person got to give up to pursue a University career, to pursue a career as a teacher? Just the other day, one Institute of Education official complained to me that their lecturers were being paid no better than teachers themselves. These lecturers are teachers to teachers. If the morale of these lecturers is low, then they can only present glum faces to the teachers who will, in turn, present glum faces to the pupils.

    Now, what about the so-called brilliant 8% that the Report extols? Here, I think there is a danger that because they are recognised as brilliant, we might overload them. The proposal to introduce a third language at some stage is one which I would not support.

    What about the values and attitudes of these people? Having the bilingual capability, having eight distinctions and so on do not necessarily make these people good leaders.

Column: 261

If I may quote from one Minister whom I overheard in the Member's Room, he said, "What good is it to me to have a First Class Honours Permanent Secretary if that fellow is not practical?" He has a point. Another person in an exalted capacity said, "Under the new system, I would not have survived. I am a monolinguist." How many people in this Chamber would have survived? Do we make enough room? In other words, is there a necessary correlation between intellect and linguistic ability? And if there is none, is there sufficient leeway in the system for transference or for emergence of the brilliant monolinguist, or even the above average monolinguist? I have trouble as I read through the Report on streaming. To go from the higher step down to the lower step, yes, it is very easy. It is like falling off the ladder. To climb up the ladder, both primary and secondary, the language is quite a barrier. I think the Education Ministry should look more carefully at this problem.

    On the flexibility which is given to parents, it is a good gesture. But at the same time I am just wondering what the end result would be if the parents all sign for their children to be admitted to the higher streams of education. Is there indeed sufficient room for the late developer?

    Let me get down to the objective of education. The Goh Report simply puts it that the basic objective is to achieve literacy in at least one language. The Prime Minister is more ambitious as usual. In the second paragraph, he says:

    'It was, and is to educate a child to bring out his greatest potential, so that he will grow up into a good man and a useful citizen.'

I have no quarrel with either the Prime Minister or the Deputy Prime Minister on the stated objective. I would just like to emphasise a few points. One is that from my observation, even university students do not know how to think for themselves. It is a surprising statement but it is a statement of fact. Because they have been programmed right throughout the school system to be recipients, to be like a computer taking in some input and providing some output.

Column: 262

When students organise seminars nowadays, they turn to lecturers and also to people outside, established in their fields, to come and speak. In my time when we organised seminars, we were the ones who were the speakers at the seminars. When we had debates, we thought through the ideas ourselves. I took part in many debates. We thought through. We did not go up to lecturers to ask for ideas. But now the university teams come up to us and say, "Can you give us ideas on this subject because, if you don't, the other team will win because they are approaching Professor so-and-so." It is something serious for us to think about.

    Here, I go back to my good friend Confucius, and I quote him in CL3 (Chinese as a Lower Second Language): 
   xue er bu si ze wang    (                 )
   si er bu xue ze dai     (                 )
"He who learns without thinking is lost. He who thinks without learning is in great danger." I might add, "dangerous to others and to society as well," Our students also need to have the ability to select. Singapore is a small open economy.
